title: Get Gill Sans Free
content:
Oh my god, this person has no idea.   
   
In order to allow the user to view her site the way she intended, she offers the fonts she's used to anyone who wants them for free....clueless!   
   
 [http://www.mynameiskate.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415131147/http:/www.mynameiskate.com/)
author: union

comments.content:
What about the Mac users? Will they not be able to see the site as she intended?   
:D

I've just sent her an email. I suggested if she took 'em down right away I wouldn't say anything to Monotype....   
   
Amazing that she's so clueless, seeing as she works in tech support and used to do DTP.   
   
T

OKay, I'm sorry, but are we going to become the font police all the sudden?   
   
Sure, she shouldn't be doing it, but come on. Sending a letter suggesting her to take them down is fine, but threatining to call Monotype on her, isn't that going a little too far?   
   
   
You can put your monotype email addresses back in your rolodex anyway, considering she's taken them down.

I thought it was kinda cute.   
   
hhp

Chris:   
   
Normally if I found a web site illegally distributing pirated fonts, I would simply inform the relevant foundry or foundries, and let them deal with it. As far as I'm concerned, I'm doing her a big favor by simply sending her a private email. It is a lot less intimidating than getting a letter from a lawyer, which is what many larger foundries do as their first step.   
   
Nobody is making YOU fight crime. But you can take a hike if you are suggesting that there's something wrong with me suggesting obeying the law in such a gentle fashion with people who threaten the livelihoods of me and my colleagues who make typefaces.   
   
T

\> you can take a hike   
   
Please desist from using such highly offensive language, otherwise I'll have   
to stop ignoring the fact that you're not ignoring all my posts to Typophile... ;-\>   
   
hhp

Thomas, considering that her site is a measly little personal site, and that it hasn't been updated in several months, I question the fact that her and her two files are seriously impinging on your livelihood or anyone else's for that matter. We're probably the most traffic she's gotten this past year.   
   
Also, I did not say there was anything wrong with you; please reread my original statement before taking things to the level of ad hominem.   
   
Now that being said, I could see it if she had tens or hundreds of fonts and was advertising "FREE FONTS HERE", but she wasn't. To threaten to call Monotype on her for two files is not doing her a favour. Threats for anything are obscene, especially if you come out with one your first time up to bat.

I disagree with your final analysis, Chris. I think the full potential ramifications of distributing fonts illegally should be plainly stated up front. This is not a threat, it is a warning of legal culpability, and it should be delivered 'your first time up to bat'. Stringing someone along in a protracted negotiation about their offering of someone else's property without warning them in no uncertain terms of the consequences of their actions is not doing them any favours. While you're faffing around trying to be nice, someone else might have already alerted Monotype, without benefit of a warning.

Well Tomas gets my vote on that one. He is too kind.   
   
If that little misfit gives a beer for a typo I figure Tomas should get a life time supply of this groggy stuff.   
   
 [http://www.pyramidbrew.com/beer/beerguide.php](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415131147/http:/www.pyramidbrew.com/beer/beerguide.php)   
   
Gerald Giampa

I guess he gets another one of those brewskies because I spelled Thomas wrong?   
   
Sorry, back to the coffee pot.   
   
Gerald

Her site may be a small personal site, but it came up number 3 in a google search on something fonts related I was after.   
   
I am keen to go get together a possie and hit some proper font pirates, Limewire anyone?
Jim, I'm sure the RIAA would love to have you on board...

haha... I think there is huge difference between riping off Madonna with her millions and ripping of Atomic Media a small foundry who as far as I know don't have millions. (see Limewire)   
   
A friend of mine who runs a big London design agency asked me why I started Union, when 'no one buys fonts anymore'....

Related anecdote:   
A friend of mine was emailed to not use his band name by someone who claimed that they got it first and used it in recordings, etc. The guy worked/ works at BMG, and felt the need to draft a threatening legal letter.   
   
As a result, my friend, feeling unduly threatened, responded in a harsh, unappreciative tone and it turned into a (verbal) fight. Ultimately, it wasn't even an issue, as the band had already parted ways, but the whole thing could have been resolved nicely had the guy just said, "You know, I have a band with the same name. Are you guys still together? Because we are, and we want to use the name we've recorded under since 19XX." He presumed that there would be a fight, rather than presuming that they could talk like adults and come to an understanding.   
   
I'm interested to see if she'll respond, and if so, how she'll respond.

"A friend of mine who runs a big London design agency asked me why I started Union, when 'no one buys fonts anymore'...."   
   
That's a very valid question.   
   
Don't get me wrong...stealing is stealing, but the reality is the digital age has changed things while the business side is still finding it tough to accept that fact and react appropriately.

Chris its interesting that you wanted to resolve the dispute acting as one adult talking to another. I'm a recreational bicycle racer and when I have to deal with cars that have road rage, I do a few things, if are swearing at me I either wave to them and say "have a nice day" or if I can catch them at a light I remind them I'm an adult and lets talk as adults or I pretend not to know english and thank them for their insults (I look German), you know what the reaction usually is, they get even madder, because they can't get you into an emotional state. Dan

When I get into a shoving match in traffic and eventually get my way, I smile and wave thank you, as if they graciously let me go ahead first. Man does that piss them off!   
   
hhp

Yeah, the 'have a nice day' response is great (speaking generally, since I'm not a bicyclist). The people who leap to agressive/ obnoxious responses often want you to validate their choice by responding in kind. The look on their face when they realize they're powerless to push you is great.

In Paris you don't get the chance to say 'have a nice day'. They run you over first, ask questions later. Mind you, I was nearly run over by a cyclist once. He ended up throwing his bike at me.   
   
M.

There's this story about an Armenian poet from the turn of the [previous] century who was a Stoic. He got in a carriage accident in Constantinople, and the other guy ended up twisting his arm to the breaking point. He says: "Please don't break my arm - I need it to write."   
   
hhp

i don't understand the Monotype threat issue. As said, it wasn't hard to say "hey, it's forbidden to do this, you know, if a dork see it, he could be mean". Or a font value moralisation i could understand too.   
Delation. Nice thing. Make me think of other ages.

Nathan, the most dangerous place to ride a bike in the US is Florida. A woman plowed into a group of 40 cyclists in Fla killing 20+ her defense: I didn't see them. The Manhattan cycling scene is huge. My club Century Road Club Association is the largest club in the country and the oldest. Most of the riding here is on a Rte 9W that goes north to Canada.
